summary: The affable Leonard Vole (Tyrone Power) is being tried for the murder of a wealthy woman, and legendary lawyer Sir Wilfrid Robarts (Charles Laughton) has chosen to represent him. This is the worst Agatha Christie mystery I have ever seen. The essence of Christie is to fill the play with subtle clues and let the audience sort them out. The essence of this play is total misdirection: to have the defendant and chief witnesses appear to be exactly the opposite of who they really are. Also, important circumstantial evidence is totally inconsistent with guilt. For example, the window broken from the outside. The defendant wouldn't have broken the window from the outside because he was a friend of the murdered woman. The woman's assistant was not a credible witness because she was hard-of-hearing and had a financial motive to lie. The letters were not credible because they would have been mailed to Germany, And, the trial itself was preposterous.  Lawyers are not allowed to yell at and argue with witnesses like that.

Out of the many Billy Wilder films I've seen, this one is now counted highly among my favorites for it yet again features the crisp and cutting dialogue and memorable characters that the director is known for. Of course, the ever-dominating Charles Laughton takes centerstage, bringing out not just the terse, piercing, piggish, rudeness of Robarts, but also the character's witty humor and ultimate good nature. Marlene Dietrich, as well, astounds as the volatile and cold Christine, imbuing each scene with magnetism and what could just be called simple awe.

A fun and creative Agatha Christie whodunnit with the added twists of the procedural investigation being conducted in a courtroon rather than with the estimable Hercule Poirot in some exotic locale. In his place we have Charles Laughton, who tosses every trope you might think of for a stuffy English barrister - fussy, detail-obsessed, clever, fastidious, intolerable, and brimming with dry humor - a brings them to life in Sir Wilfrid Robarts. Pitted against him is the mysterious Christine Vole, played with equal capability by the great Marlene Dietrich, whose motives and role in the murder remain fluid and undecided until the film's final moments. 

Perhaps I let this particular film hang around a bit too long in the list of world classics of cinema; I walked away having expected slightly more than what I got. The performances were very nice (particularly Dietrich's puzzling persona and Laughton's charming curmudgeon), but the plot itself swings around in fits and starts, with a humorous introduction to Sir Wilfrid's character followed by protracted periods of flashbacks that serves mostly as context for the more engaging courtroon scenes and the final twist reveal. Still, it all comes together as material to flesh out each of the individual characters and provide more of a justification for the dueling of personalities rather than dry fact, and makes for a very entertaining film regardless. 

It is always great to see Laughton bicker with his real-life wife, Elsa Lanchester, in some of their shared films; their chemistry is undeniable and translates so well to the screen. (3.5/5)

Billy Wilder's courtroom drama mystery Witness for the Prosecution (1957) asks us how a jury, witnesses, lawyers, and laws can be manipulated in a court of law. I find Wilder's direction riveting with astonishing confidence in establishing all of writer Agatha Christie's intricate legal details and mystery clues for the audience to unfold. Christie's writing ruminates on the role of witnesses in a trial and how someone can interpret testimony. Wilder's focused direction hones in on each detail to hint to the viewer as to what is really going on throughout Witness for the Prosecution, while also getting laughs from Wilder's playful sense of humor.

Marlene Dietrich steals the show with a powerful femme fatale role as Christine Vole, who curiously chooses to swear under oath as a witness for the prosecution against her own husband. She is fascinating with every sly glance and revealing word. Marlene is always drop dead gorgeous, effortlessly enthralling, and dramatically flirty. She commands the silver screen with her awesome star power, heavy gravitas, and captivating dramatic performance. Tyrone Power is excellent as Marlene Dietrich's husband, the defendant Leonard Vole, who is desperately pleading with jurors to accept his innocence.

Charles Laughton is delightful as the stuffy and fastidious barrister Sir Wilfrid Robarts. He's a by the book defense lawyer with extreme precision and intuition. Laughton's funny, booming voiced lawyer Robarts is a pleasure to watch, especially alongside his real life wife Elsa Lanchester as the meticulous and stubborn Nurse Plimsoll. They have wonderful chemistry on screen together with hilarious comedic timing. 

John Williams is steadfast as the other lawyer Brogan-Moore, while Henry Daniell has an interesting presence as the solicitor Mayhew. Ian Wolfe's dedicated butler Carter is funny next to Laughton's brilliant lawyer trying to sneak cigars, booze, and additional legal counsel. I liked the friendly and inviting Norma Varden as the wealthy widow Miss Emily Jane French. Irish actress Una O'Connor is a riot as the mean and accusatory maid Janet McKenzie. Ruta Lee even cameos as Diana in the crowd witnessing the trial.

In my opinion, if 12 Angry Men is the best film about jury deliberation, The Verdict is the best film about lawyers, Legally Blonde is the best film about cross-examining witnesses, To Kill a Mockingbird is the best film about why a lawyer should represent a defendant, Judgement at Nuremberg is the best film about judges, then Witness for the Prosecution is the best film about witnesses. I think that I was questioning every suspect, motive, and opportunity all the time while enjoying Witness for the Prosecution. I was enthralled by every minute of Wilder's twisting legal picture with Agatha Christie's startling story. Witness for the Prosecution is a must see classic that redefines how you look at courtroom dramas and legal proceedings.

Daniel Mandell's editing keeps 116 minutes feeling like 30 with sharp cuts and no unnecessary scenes. Russell Harlan's cinematography has lovely wide shots, but it is his stunning close-ups that reveal whether a character is telling the truth. Alexandre Trauner's art direction is breathtaking with a stark contrast in court between nervous witnesses and calm lawyers to the more rigid English society appearances outside the courtroom. Howard Bristol's set decoration ensures every courtroom and law office looks finely furnished and proper.

Matty Malneck's score has an air of mysterious atmosphere and intense romanticism. He composes an intense accompaniment to this legal thriller. Edith Head's fashionable suits for Marlene Dietrich are to die for honestly. Wally Westmore's make-up artistry crafts Marlene's face into film perfection.

To summarize, Witness for the Prosecution gets at the heart of why people testify and what laws can do in the right and wrong hands.

Inventor Leonard Vole, Tyrone Power, is suspected of murdering the elderly Mrs. Emily French, Norma Varden, to gain access to the money she had left him in her will. Vole hires famed barrister Sir Wilfrid Robards, Charles Laughton, to defend him but Robards is facing significant health problems and is under the watchful eye of his nurse Miss Plimsoll, Elsa Lanchester, who annoys him greatly. Robards defends his client, believing he is guilty, but their case is complicated by the fact that Vole's German wife Christine, Marlene Dietrich, serves as a witness for the prosecution as she claims that she and Vole are not officially married as she is actually married to a German man and accuses her husband of being guilty. Robards wins the case because he is able to find evidence that suggests that Christine was lying. Revelations about the source of his information leave him confounded and his loyalties must shift.

Few directors have as light a touch as Wilder as he produces possibly the best film adaptation of an Agatha Christie novel by leaning into the comedic aspects of her stories and playing to the talents of his cast. He is able to propel the film along at a relatively quick pace making us more invested in the characters than in the courtroom drama. He gives Laughton, Lanchester and especially Dietrich room to play and there is that occasional touch of melancholy that he would put to such good use in The Apartment (1960). He doesn't get lost in unnecessary details surrounding the mystery as some directors would have and gives the film an episodic structure that is somewhat necessary with a film like this. He was deserving of his Best Director nomination as while few would count this among his strongest work he pulls together a story that could have fallen into disarray in the hands of a lesser director such as Kenneth Branagh.

The performances are really what needs to be discussed because as much as Wilder's sure hand is indispensable he needs the work of a talent like Laughton to make the film shine. He has bluster and more than enough gravitas to make us slightly afraid when he takes against those around him but he is also playful and charming in his own way. He finds particular inspiration in scenes when he is asked to engage in verbal sparring with Lanchester as his put downs of her and prissiness in response to her properness elicits laughter. Much must also be said of Lanchester who is delightfully buttoned up in a role that gives her some great dialogue to work with and allows her to put her guileless expressions to good use. Power makes an interesting murder suspect as he is effectively mercurial, likable at one moment and sinister at the next, with his use as a supporting actor being better than his efforts as a leading man in The Mask of Zorro (1940). Even Ruta Lee, who only has about five minutes of screen time, is deliciously nasty and rude in the way that only villains in Wilder movies can be as she has touches of Fred MacMurray as Jeff D. Sheldrake.

To a modern audience this may seem like a strange choice for a Best Picture nomination but in comparison to the more traditionally prestigious Sayonara (1957) and Peyton Place (1957) this is a masterpiece.

Review In A Nutshell:

I am not the most experienced viewer when it comes to courtroom or legal drama, as I never really found the genre all that compelling, but my recent viewing of 12 Angry Men, opened my eyes to the electrifying experience of murder, affairs, and drama being told without the aid of visual spectacle.

Witness for the Prosecution contains similarities to 12 Angry Men, where the audience is left in the dark and could only shape the situation or its characters from the words being spoken; the film doesn't give us a visual glimpse of truth. This film is a perfect example that demonstrates the power of words; the film's dialogue is responsible for shaping its characters, moving the plot, and establishing its atmosphere. Each time a word was being said, I was learning more and more about the characters and the situation, my curiosity never at one point faded, then the film brings us in the courtroom where the heat is turned up, filling the room with so much drama and intensity that not once did I turn away from the screen. It was a splendid idea to have the film's protagonist to come off at first as unpleasant, in order to have its third act feel all the more powerful, and also it strays away from the typical leading men in films similar to this. Very few films could match the energy and strength of Billy Wilder and Harry Kurnitz's script, which is exactly the reason why I am not giving much of the film's plot or characters away.

I was glad to see that this film wasn't overly directed by Wilder, placing complete faith to his script. Less is certainly sometimes more, Witness for the Prosecution's approachable story and entertaining characters is enough to keep its audience interested, there was no need for Wilder to add flair to the film's camerawork as that would have probably given the film too much ambiguity, as to enjoy this film one must take in the information straight; don't over think, just let it flow through you. The story may be strong, but it doesn't compare to Wilder's exploration of a self-destructing man who is driven in his career and will stop at nothing to claim justice for his client. I was cringing as each time he did something to further damage is state of health, and was baffled at the poor work his nurse was doing, particularly at the end of the film.

Charles Laughton, I adore you in this film and I sincerely hope there would be more performances just like this one as I go further into your filmography; I am aware that the possibility of him reading this would be close to none but I cannot express my gratitude for his work here in any other form. Tyrone Power as Leonard Vole was also strong in this film, and thankfully many shots of him aren't together with Laughton or else I wouldn't have even noticed the great performance he delivered. Marlene Dietrich was certainly one of the film's weakest aspects, as her performance felt too contrived and lacked that flavour that makes her performance believable.

Witness for the Prosecution is possibly my favourite film from director Billy Wilder; at least so far, as it displays a dominating performance by Laughton and a story that certainly delivers the thrills that many films in its genre simply couldn't match.

Each time a word was being said, I was learning more and more about the characters and the situation, my curiosity never at one point faded, then the film brings us in the courtroom where the heat is turned up, filling the room with so much drama and intensity that not once did I turn away from the screen. It was a splendid idea to have the film's protagonist to come off at first as unpleasant, in order to have its third act feel all the more powerful, and also it strays away from the typical leading men in films similar to this. Very few films could match the energy and strength of Billy Wilder and Harry Kurnitz's script, which is exactly the reason why I am not giving much of the film's plot or characters away.

I was glad to see that this film wasn't overly directed by Wilder, placing complete faith to his script. Less is certainly sometimes more, Witness for the Prosecution's approachable story and entertaining characters is enough to keep its audience interested, there was no need for Wilder to add flair to the film's camerawork as that would have probably given the film too much ambiguity, as to enjoy this film one must take in the information straight; don't over think, just let it flow through you. The story may be strong, but it doesn't compare to Wilder's exploration of a self-destructing man who is driven in his career and will stop at nothing to claim justice for his client. I was cringing as each time he did something to further damage is state of health, and was baffled at the poor work his nurse was doing, particularly at the end of the film.

Charles Laughton, I adore you in this film and I sincerely hope there would be more performances just like this one as I go further into your filmography; I am aware that the possibility of him reading this would be close to none but I cannot express my gratitude for his work here in any other form. Tyrone Power as Leonard Vole was also strong in this film, and thankfully many shots of him aren't together with Laughton or else I wouldn't have even noticed the great performance he delivered. Marlene Dietrich was certainly one of the film's weakest aspects, as her performance felt too contrived and lacked that flavour that makes her performance believable.

Witness for the Prosecution is possibly my favourite film from director Billy Wilder; at least so far, as it displays a dominating performance by Laughton and a story that certainly delivers the thrills that many films in its genre simply couldn't match.

In writer-director Billy Wilder's 1957 courtroom drama Witness for the Prosecution, we follow an elderly lawyer (Charles Laughton) with poor health who takes on a criminal case, much to the dissatisfaction of his private nurse (Elsa Lanchester). This case requires him to defend a man (Tyrone Power) who is accused of killing an old, rich lady (Norma Varden) whom he had developed a fond friendship with. He's accused of the crime because she made him the main acceptor of her will. 

This case becomes more complicated when the defendant's German wife (Marlene Dietrich) basically testifies against her husband because she's actually married to another man. The lawyer finds this particular part of the case strange because wives should naturally be supportive of their husbands no matter what. From there, many more complicated issues take place with attempting to solve this case that it all leads up to a shocking finale. 

This finale was so famous that the filmmakers literally put up a disclaimer at the very end of the film telling its audiences not to talk about it or give away the film's secret. You don't see that type of disclaimer nowadays anymore, do you? While I can't say that this is one of the most shocking endings ever, I will say that I do appreciate the filmmaker's attempt to keep the ending a secret as much as possible. That's more than I can say for all the movie trailers and commercials today which seem to give away too much about certain movies, though that's another subject I'll plan to tackle another time via editorial. 

One of the aspects about Witness for the Prosecution overall that I liked was the relationship between the lawyer and the nurse. I just like how this lawyer sort of does whatever he can to disobey his nurse's advice and how much this nurse unintentionally drives him nuts. I thought they handled that relationship very well. Neither of them came off as bad simply because they disagreed with each other, they just constantly got in each other's way so to speak. 

As far as courtroom dramas go, I don't think that Witness for the Prosecution is the strongest film I've seen from this genre, but I still think that this is a pretty good picture in its own right. The storytelling is pretty well focused and the acting by the likes of Laughton and Lanchester are well done. However, I'm split in regards to what I feel about the main case itself. Sometimes I was really interested in the developments that arose in the case. Other times, I wasn't either due to being unable to understand certain parts or just finding the characters involved in the case not that interesting. 

This doesn't put the film to a complete halt by any means, it just makes the better parts of the picture stand out more. As a whole, Witness for the Prosecution does what it was intended to do. If you like courtroom dramas in general, this film does the intended purposes a film in this genre are supposed to do and if you'll settle for that, then you won't be let down by any means.

Witness For the Prosecution is one of the greatest courtroom dramas I have ever seen--and simultaneously one of the most surprising movies I've ever seen.
The twists in the story of Witness For the Prosecution is truly impressive. That's what will make audiences remember it long after the film is over. But something else that made the picture stand out to me was the characterization it gave. I'm always impressed when genres like courtroom drama do this because it's something that doesn't really seem like it "needs" to be done. Sure the film could have been just as great without so much detail in the characters. If the audience had never become so close with the character of the defense attorney and the way his health is deteriorating and his refusal to abandon old habits like cigar smoking, they would have been fine. But those extra details are always what makes a good film a great film, and the same applies here.
The plot is fantastically done, as I have already said. This is largely with thanks to the screenplay written by Larry Marcus, Billy Wilder, and Harry Kurnitz. This screenplay has audiences at the edge of their seats every moment and at no point does it let up. 
Now Billy Wilder is absolutely fantastic as a director. This is my fifth Billy Wilder film(Sunset Boulevard, Double Indemnity, Some Like it Hot, and The Apartment in chronological viewing order), yet my least favorite in terms of direction style. Not that he lacks any, but Witness For the Prosecution is unfortunately low in its visual stamina. I have known Billy Wilder to sneak in some pretty intriguing visuals of some kind, whether they be in the sets, costumes, or camera styles, but Witness For the Prosecution did not have as much of that.
Even so, this is a smash of a courtroom drama and a must-see for any fan of the genre.
